ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Bandgap evolution of GaN1−x As x in the whole composition range

Affiliation.OrgDivision: School of Electronics and Information Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The bandgap evolution of GaN1−x As x in the whole composition range is investigated and a model describing its bandgap energy is developed. It is found that the bandgap evolution is due to two factors. One is the interaction between the impurity band and the Γ conduction band or the Γ valence band of the host materials. The other one is the intraband coupling within the conduction band and separately within the valence band. The former is dominant in the As-rich GaNAs and the N-rich GaNAs. The latter plays an important part in the N-rich range and the moderate composition range.

Body.Para: GaNAs has attracted much attention due to their potential applications in microelectronic and optoelectronic devices. Unlike the conventional III–V semiconductor alloys, the bandgap energy of GaN1−x As x exhibits a very strongly nonlinear variation. Wei and Zunger calculated the bandgap energy of GaN1−x As x in a very large composition range [1]. However, they do not give a formula to describe its compositional dependence, which shows that it is hard to obtain the compositional dependence of the bandgap energy of GaN1−x As x . Since Shan et al. successfully used the band-anticrossing (BAC) model to describe the dependence of the bandgap energy of InGaNAs on their compositions [2], the BAC model has been widely used to describe the dependence of the bandgap energy of III–V dilute nitride semiconductor alloys on their compositions, including the As-rich GaN1−x As x . [3–9]. For the N-rich GaN1−x As x , Several groups used the equation with a bowing term to describe its band gap energy [10–13]. However, it does not describe the bandgap evolution with composition very well. In order to solve the problem, Zhao et al. developed a model describing the bandgap energy of the N-rich GaNAs [14, 15]. The evolution of the conduction band and the valence band in the moderate composition range is not clear, and very few investigations on the bandgap energy of GaNAs in the whole composition range have been reported. In this paper, we will discuss the evolution of the conduction band and the valence band in the whole composition range and develop a model to describe the bandgap energy of GaN1−x As x .

Before discussing the band evolution and developing a model for the bandgap energy of GaN1−x As x in the whole composition range, several assumptions are made: (1) The energy of the valence band maximum (VBM) and the conduction band minimum (CBM) in GaN are 0 eV and 3.42 eV, respectively. (2) The conduction band of GaNAs can be described by a flat alignment of the conduction band between GaAs and GaN before considering the strong bowing of the conduction band. (3) The strong bowing of the CBM can be described by the linear interpolation according to the bowing of the CBM in the As-rich side and the N-rich side. (4) The variation of the VBM in the whole composition range is similar to the variation of the VBM in the N-rich GaNAs.

Figure 1 shows the dependence of the CBM and the VBM on As content for GaN1−x As x . The experimental values are from the literature [16, 17]. From Fig. 1, it can be seen that the whole composition range can be divided into three regions. They are A, B, and C, respectively.
Fig. 1
Dependence of CBM and VBM on the As content for GaN1−x As x

(I) The A composition range can be considered as the N-rich region and the host material is GaN. In this region the CBM can be considered to decrease linearly and the VBM increases sharply, which causes a large bandgap reduction. The large bandgap reductions for the N-rich GaNAs are relative to two factors. One is the intraband coupling within the conduction band and the valence band. With increasing As content, the intraband coupling becomes strong, which can lower the CBM and raise the VBM [14]. The other factor is the As level above the VBM of GaN. It is found that the As level are highly localized and the localized As level has a large influence on the VBM [13, 15]. When the As content is large enough, the As level above the VBM of GaN forms As band. The As band can pin the VBM near the As level in GaNAs [14]. In Fig. 1, it is clear to be seen that the VBM is pinned near the As level in the content ranging from 2 % to 10 %. The work done by Wu et al. also proves this opinion [10].

(II) In the B composition range, the VBM shifts to higher energy slowly and the CBM weakly shifts to lower energy with increasing As content, which shows that the intraband coupling within the conduction band and separately within the valence band is dominated in the B composition range. The calculation done by Bellaiche et al. also shows that the CBM and the VBM vary little in the composition range although the variation of the CBM and the VBM is not monotonous in their calculation [16]. The small shift of the VBM and the CBM shows that the intraband coupling within the conduction band and separately within the valence band varies little.

(III) The C composition range is usually considered as the As-rich region and the host materials is GaAs. In the region, The evolution of the CBM is very different from that in the A and B composition ranges. The difference is due to the different physical mechanisms. In the C composition range, the large variation of the CBM is due to the strong coupling interaction between the N level and the CBM of GaAs. For the VBM of the As-rich GaNAs, its variation is small. The small variation of the VBM can be attributed to the coupling interaction between the N level and the VBM of GaAs. The reason is as follows. The coupling interaction is dependent on the energy difference between the N level and the VBM of GaAs. It is found that the energy difference between them is very large. The large energy difference shows that the coupling interaction between the N level and the VBM of GaAs is so small that it could not push down the VBM very much.

After understanding the evolution of the CBM and the VBM with the composition, we can investigate the bandgap energy of the GaNAs in the whole composition range. Based on the assumptions (1) and (2), the CBM before considering the strong bowing of the conduction band can be given as follows:
1
$$ E_{C,\mathrm{VCA}}(x) = E_{C,\mathrm{GaN}}, $$ where E
C,GaN is the CBM of GaN.

For the As-rich GaNAs, the BAC model can describe its bandgap energy very well. As the contribution from the valence band is not considered in the BAC model, the variation of the bandgap energy is only from the conduction band. The variation of the CBM in the As-rich GaNAs can be given in the following form:
2
$$\begin{aligned} \Delta E_{\mathrm{CBM},\mathrm{As}\mbox{-}\mathrm{rich}} &= E_{g,\mathrm{GaAs}} - \frac{1}{2} \bigl[ E_{N} + E_{M} \\ &\quad {} \pm \sqrt{(E_{N} - E_{M})^{2} + 4(V_{MN})^{2}(1 - x)}\, \bigr], \end{aligned}$$ where E
N is the energy of the N-related level relative to the top of the valence band. C
MN is a term describing coupling between the N level and the Γ conduction band. E
M is the energy of the CBM of GaAs. E
g,GaAs corresponds to the bandgap energy of GaAs. In this calculation, E
M =E
g,GaAs=1.42 eV and E
N =1.65 eV are used. C
MN is an empirical parameter which has to be determined experimentally.

The CBM of the N-rich GaNAs is considered to decrease linearly with increasing As content so its variation can be given in the following form [14]:
3
$$ \Delta E_{CBM,N\mbox{-}rich} = \alpha x, $$ where α is a fitting parameter which describes the CBM evolution of the N-rich GaNAs.

Based on the assumption (3), the variation of the CBM in the whole composition range can be given in the following form:
4
$$ \Delta E_{C} = \Delta E_{\mathrm{CBM},\mathrm{As}\mbox{-}\mathrm{rich}}x + \Delta E_{\mathrm{CBM},\mathrm{N}\mbox{-}\mathrm{rich}} (1 - x). $$

For the VBM of GaNAs, the linear interpolation of the VBM between the end point compounds (GaN and GaAs) was used in Ref. [17]. Figure 1 shows the result. It is found that the deviation between the result of the linear interpolation and the experiment is very large. For the VBM of the N-rich GaNAs, Zhao et al. considered that its variation with increasing As content could be in analogy to the commonly observed bandgap narrowing in heavily doped semiconductors and its evolution with As content x could be written in the following form [14, 15]:
5
$$ \Delta E_{V} = \beta \sqrt{x}, $$ where β is a fitting parameter which describes the VBM variation of the N-rich GaNAs. In this work, we assume that the variation of the VBM for GaN1−x As x in the whole composition range can be described by the variation of the VBM in the N-rich GaNAs. Based on the assumption (4), the VBM of the GaNAs in the whole composition range can be written as
6
$$ E_{V,\mathrm{GaNAs}}(x) = E_{V,\mathrm{GaN}} + \Delta E_{V}, $$ where E
V,GaN is the energy of the VBM for GaN. In order to ensure E
V,GaNAs(0)=0 eV and E
V,GaNAs(1)=2.0 eV, the parameter β should be equal to 2.0 eV. Figure 1 shows the result. It can be seen that Eq. (6) can describe the evolution of the VBM very well, which shows that it is reasonable to use Eq. (6) to describe the VBM of GaNAs. It is found that the energetic location of the valence band is nearly independent of the N content in GaN1−x As x alloys when the As content is larger than x>97 % [18]. If we use Eq. (6) to describe the evolution of the VBM, the variation of the VBM is not larger than 30 meV in the composition range (x>97 %). which agrees well with the experiment. In Fig. 1 it can be also found that Eq. (6) can describe the evolution of the VBM better than virtual crystal approximation (VCA).

From Eqs. (1)–(6), the bandgap energy of GaNAs in the whole composition range can be written as
7
$$ E_{g,\mathrm{GaNAs}}(x) = E_{C,\mathrm{VCA},\mathrm{GaNAs}} - \Delta E_{C,\mathrm{GaNAs}} - E_{V,\mathrm{GaNAs}}. $$

We use Eq. (7) to fit the experimental data and obtain α=3.15 eV and C
MN =2.15 eV. Figure 2 shows the dependence of the bandgap energy of GaNAs on composition in the whole composition range. The experimental data are from the literature [6, 10, 11, 16, 17, 19]. It can be seen that the model can describe the bandgap energy of GaNAs very well. The model developed by Wu et al. is also shown in Fig. 2. Compared with the experimental values, it is found that the model in this work is better in agreement than the model developed by Wu et al., especially when the As content is in the moderate composition range and less than 1 %. For GaNAs with As content less than 1 %, we consider that the influence of the As level on the VBM is not large enough to lower the bandgap energy of GaNAs so much because the As level is only an isolated level when the As content is very small [15].
Fig. 2
Dependence of the bandgap energy of GaN1−x As x on As content x

In addition, it can be seen that the calculated minimum of the bandgap energy in this work is about 0.33 eV at x=0.67. The result obtained by Bellaiche et al. showed that the minimum of the bandgap energy was about 0.36 eV at x=0.55 [16], which agrees well with our result. The model developed by Wu et al. showed that the minimum was about 0.7 eV at x=0.8 [13] and the calculation done by Reilly et al. showed that the minimum was about 0.2 eV at x=0.55 [20]. Our value is in the range of their results, which leads us to believe that this predicted minimum of the bandgap energy in GaNAs is physically justifiable.

In conclusion, the bandgap evolution of GaNAs in the whole composition range is investigated. It is found that the bandgap evolution is due to two factors. One is the coupling interaction between the impurity band and the Γ conduction band or the Γ valence band of the host materials. The other one is intraband coupling within the conduction band and separately within the valence band. In addition, we develop a model to describe the bandgap energy of GaNAs in the whole composition range. The model may also be used to calculate the bandgap energy of other group III–N–V nitrides. In order to improve the accuracy of the parameters in the model, further experimental work should be done.
